Interactive Guide to Cross-Platform UI Input & Focus

An exploration of how UI components behave across different input methods. Use the filters below to compare platforms and components.

Filter by Platform:

Universal Principles

Keyboard/Tab Focus (Desktop/Mac)

  • Order (Tab Index): Focus must move logically through the UI, typically left-to-right, top-to-bottom, following the visual flow.
  • Visibility: Every focusable element must display a clear, high-contrast **Focus Ring** or outline to show the user where they are.
  • Mac Default: macOS may require users to enable "Full Keyboard Access" in System Settings to allow the Tab key to focus on all controls.

Touch Focus (Android/Mobile)

  • Implicit Focus: Focus is typically given implicitly upon tapping. Tapping a text field activates it and brings up the keyboard.
  • Accessibility Services (e.g., TalkBack): For screen reader users, focus is managed by swiping to move an "accessibility focus" between elements, which are then highlighted and read aloud.

Trackpad/Touchpad Nuances (Mac)

  • Gestures: Mac trackpads rely heavily on multi-touch gestures (two-finger scroll, pinch-to-zoom). Developers must ensure these OS-level gestures don't conflict with in-app interactions.
  • Haptic Feedback & Force Touch: Trackpads provide haptic feedback. A "deep press" or "Force Touch" can be used for secondary actions like previews, offering a unique input method not available on most other devices.
